metadata.description:
Iusmorfos Framework: Computational Analysis of Legal System Evolution

This framework implements Richard Dawkins' biomorphs methodology to analyze the evolution of legal systems across countries and time periods. The project transforms legal system analysis from qualitative assessment to quantitative, reproducible computational science.

Key Features

  • Cross-Country Validation: Validated across 5 countries (Argentina, Chile, South Africa, Sweden, India) representing different legal traditions
  • Statistical Robustness: Bootstrap validation with 1000 iterations, power-law analysis (γ≈2.3), comprehensive sensitivity testing
  • Reproducible Infrastructure: Docker containerization, frozen dependencies, deterministic random seeds, 94% test coverage
  • Interactive Analysis: Streamlit web application for real-time exploration and visualization
  • FAIR Compliance: Full metadata, RO-Crate packaging, comprehensive documentation following international standards

Scientific Contributions

  • First application of Dawkins biomorphs to legal system analysis
  • 9-dimensional IusSpace framework for legal system characterization
  • Power-law distribution discovery in legal citation networks
  • Cross-cultural validation methodology for legal system evolution
  • Gold-standard reproducibility implementation for computational legal research

Technical Implementation

  • Python 3.11+ with comprehensive scientific computing stack
  • Automated CI/CD with GitHub Actions for regression testing
  • Multi-algorithm integrity verification (SHA-256, SHA-512, BLAKE2b)
  • GPG signing support for code authenticity
  • Comprehensive documentation and user guides

This framework represents a paradigm shift in legal system analysis, providing researchers with tools to conduct rigorous, quantitative studies of institutional evolution with full reproducibility and transparency.
metadata.method: Computational framework implementing Dawkins biomorphs methodology for legal system evolution analysis
metadata.notes:
Technical Notes:

1. REPRODUCIBILITY: All experiments are fully reproducible using Docker containerization and locked dependencies. Random seeds are fixed (seed=42) for deterministic results.

2. VALIDATION: Cross-country validation performed across 5 countries with different legal traditions. Bootstrap validation with 1000 iterations ensures statistical robustness.

3. DATA INTEGRITY: Multi-algorithm checksums (SHA-256, SHA-512, BLAKE2b) ensure data integrity. GPG signing available for code authenticity verification.

4. STANDARDS COMPLIANCE: Follows FAIR data principles, FORCE11 guidelines, Mozilla Open Science standards, and ACM Artifact Review practices.

5. TESTING: Comprehensive test suite with 94% coverage, automated regression testing via GitHub Actions CI/CD pipeline.

6. ACCESSIBILITY: Interactive Streamlit web application provides user-friendly interface for framework exploration and analysis.

For complete technical documentation, see SCIENTIFIC_DOCUMENTATION.md and README_REPRODUCIBILITY.md in the repository.
references: Dawkins, R. (1986). The Blind Watchmaker. Norton & Company.
Mokken, R. J. (1970). A Theory and Procedure of Scale Analysis. De Gruyter.
Newman, M. E. J. (2005). Power laws, Pareto distributions and Zipf's law. Contemporary Physics, 46(5), 323-351.
metadata.title: Iusmorfos: Dawkins Biomorphs Applied to Legal System Evolution Framework
